titlegroup.title: 3 Adjectives: Order within DP and Attributive APs

li.p: Adjective placement as an argument for N-movement (Cinque 1990a, 1992; Valois 1991a, 1991b, 1996)
DP and clausal structures: adjectives in event nominals
Adjunction vs. specifiers and serialization of adjectives
Challenges for the derivational analysis and semantics-based approach

subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: Not unlike adverbs (see chapter 4), the study of adjectives and adjective ordering is a difficult and complex one. Aside from interpretation considerations of the various adjective types, two different problems have been the object of much research in the field: the ordering of adjectival strings per se, and the relative ordering of adjectives and the noun they modify in various languages (see also chapter 2).

These two main areas of research have been developed substantially over the last few years in large part due to our improved understanding of the structure of Determiner Phrases (DP) and their various components. This has enabled researchers to tackle the adjective ordering problem in a systematic and principled way.
Here, we first look at some of the earlier work with respect to adjective ordering, then move on to discuss some of the more influential proposals concerning the aforementioned problems.

subsection.heading: 2 Predication and attribution
subsection.p: Variation in terminology and classification notwithstanding, adjectives are usually divided into two categories: predicative and non-predicative (for detailed discussions of adjective types, see Bolinger 1967; Kamp 1975; Siegel 1980; Higginbotham 1985; Keenan and Faltz 1985; Giorgi and Longobardi 1991). Generally, predicative adjectives describe a property that is predicated of the set of individuals denoted by the noun, while non-predicative adjectives do not. This distinction usually correlates with the adjective's capacity to appear with a copula (null or not) or with a verb in a reduced relative construction; predicative adjectives do, while non-predicative adjectives establish a relation with a noun without an intermediate copula (see Bolinger 1967; Cinque 1994). 1
This differentiates, for instance, round from alleged in (1):

(1)
a. The round table. (round = property of the set of tables)
b. The table is round.
c. The alleged communist. (alleged ≠ property of the set of communists)
d. *The communist is alleged.

Predicative adjectives can be further divided into intersective and non-intersective adjectives. The adjective round in (1) is intersective because it denotes the sets of objects that are both round and tables. This is not the case for careful in (2).
(2) A careful cook.

Here the adjective may either restrict the reference denoted by the set of cooks to only those who are careful (internal scale) or determines the set of cooks being characterized (denoting cooks that are careful as individuals, not just as cooks – external scale – see Bouchard 1998, from whom the above discussion is taken, for a more detailed discussion, and how these distinctions sometimes correlate with the pre- or postnominal position of adjectives in French).

subsection.heading: 3 Ordering
subsection.p: One major concern in the study of adjectives is ordering. Hetzron (1978) observes that, for a good number of natural languages, adjectives seem to be ordered according to semantic criteria. 2 The major rule calls for the more objective and undisputable qualifications to be closer to the noun, and the more subjective, opinion-like ones to be farther away. At one extremity of the continuum we find subjective and individual denoting adjectives, at the other objective and collective denoting adjectives. In between, there is a whole spectrum of semantic features. 3

According to Hetzron, the general cross-linguistic tendency is that adjectives that usually appear closest to the noun are those denoting purpose or destination. In prenominal position, for instance, these are preceded by adjectives denoting composition, origin, color, physical defect, shape, and finally, age.

This ordering of adjectives seems to apply independently of the position of adjectives with respect to the noun they modify, i.e., it is somewhat general. Indeed, in languages with A(djective)-N(oun) word order the ordering is exactly the mirror image of what is found in consistent NA word order. There are also ‘mixed’ languages, e.g., French, in which adjectives may appear either in pre- or postnominal position (this particular case is examined in detail in the sections below). The paradigm in (3) illustrates the distribution of a subclass of adjectives in each language type.

(3)

When two adjectives of the same class co-occur, it seems that the order is interchangeable across languages. Thus, both (4a, b) (which involve two adjectives of the human propensity class in Dixon's classification) are acceptable in English:

(4)
a. a clever brave man
b. a brave clever man

There are exceptions to the general pattern. For one, it seems that in some of the languages Hetzron examined certain adjectival categories are either interchangeable or take ordering precedence over others. For instance, some languages allow color and evaluation adjectives to interchange. One example is Polish. According to Hetzron's informants both (5a) and (5b) are acceptable “with relative ease:”

(5)
a. p ekna duża pi ka
beautiful big ball
b. duża p ekna piłka

In other languages, certain types of adjectives must occur first in the line of adjectives. This is the case for size adjectives (arguably because size qualifications are obligatorily treated as emphatic in these languages) in Japanese (also Amharic) and Romanian (as well as Spanish). As a comparison between these two language types shows, this ordering precedence is at play whether adjectives precede or follow the noun:

(6)
a. Japanese: ōki kirei na akay bōru
big pretty red ball
b. Romanian: o minge mare ro⋅ǎ (⋅i) frumoasǎ
a ball big red (and) pretty

Finally, some languages are rather free with respect to adjective ordering, which in this case depends on external factors such as context, relative emphasis, euphony, etc. Two examples are Somali (which has relatively few basic adjectives) and Kurdish, which allow all six permutations of the strings in (7a, b):

(7)
a. Somali: gabadh fiican dheer madow
girl good tall dark-skinned
gabadh fiican oo madow oo dheer
gabadh dheer oo madow oo fiican
etc.
b. Kurdish: top-a jwan-a gawr-a sur-a-ka
ball beautiful big red
top-a sur-a gawr-a jwan-a-ka
etc.

Having said this, Hetzron points out that the languages that exhibit the more general ordering (i.e. (3)) have the most elaborate systems, and he goes on to suggest that “it is the properties of adjective ordering in these languages, such as English and Hungarian, that need thorough investigation in view of establishing a general theory, while the other language types will be described as a simplification of the more complicated system, or . . . a statement has to be made to the effect that they are EXEMPT from the generalizations established for the first group” (1978: 175).

Sproat and Shi (1988) also look at adjective ordering in some detail. Their analysis aims at providing some justification for a cognitive-based account of adjective ordering. Looking at English and Mandarin Chinese, they distinguish between apparent and non-apparent adjectives. More apparent adjectives are those that denote an intrinsic property of a noun, while less apparent adjectives denote a property in relation to other objects. For instance, the adjective red describes an intrinsic property of an object since being red does not require comparing the object with other non-red objects in order to determine its color. On the other hand, large is less apparent in the sense that for an object to be considered large it needs to be compared with non-large objects: a butterfly may be large compared to other butterflies but is still smaller in real size than a large (or even a small) car. Hence, adjectives that require less comparison are more apparent, while those that require more comparison are less apparent.

With prenominal adjectives, Sproat and Shi's proposal is that the less apparent the adjective is, the further to the left in the adjective string it appears. This is exemplified by the following pairings of adjectives in English:
(8) The large red car. Size (less apparent) to the left of color (more apparent)
(9) A nice small dog. Quality to the left of size
(10) A nice green table. Quality to the left of color

Aside from the ordering problem, which they also touch upon, recent studies on adjectives have sought to give a principled analysis of the relative position of adjectives with respect to the noun in various languages. As we saw above, in some languages adjectives appear before the noun, in others they appear after the noun, yet in others they may appear in either position. The problem can be looked at either from a derivational or a representational point of view. We begin in the next section with an approach that has spawned much research in recent years: the derivational analysis.

subsection.heading: 4 Adjective placement as an argument for N-movement (Cinque 1990a, 1992; Valois 1991a, 1991b, 1996)
subsection.p: In early work in generative grammar, adjectives were generally considered to be adjoined to the intermediate N′ projection of the noun, with no real attempt at accounting in a principled way for cross-linguistic variation with respect to the relative order of adjectives and the noun they modify. Recent work has looked at this very problem. Much progress made in this area is in large part due to other important developments in syntactic theory, such as recent research on the structure of Determiner Phrases, and head-movement within the DP. These studies on adjectives are thus inseparable from these developments, and will be presented in that context here, as we provide a general overview of some of the more detailed and influential research on adjective placement.

Research in generative grammar on the structure of DP and its similarities with the structure of clauses (an idea originally put forth by Szabolcsi 1987, 1994; see also Abney 1987) has provided in the late 1980s and the 1990s a new way of looking at the distribution of adjective phrases (AP) within the DP. One important development is the proposal by Cinque (1990a) that the distribution of APs provide an argument in favor of N-movement within the DP.

It has been argued that the relative position of adverbs in English and French is a consequence of the different ways that inflectional morphology attaches to the verb in the two languages: via verb movement to an inflectional node located higher than the adverb in French, but through affix-hopping of the morphological features onto the verb in English (Emonds 1976; Pollock 1989; Chomsky 1995c) (see chapter 75). Typical examples are given below:

(11)
a. Marc often eats apples.
b. Marc mangei souvent ti des pommes.

Looking at thematic (external argument) adjectives in event (deverbal or derived) nominals (see chapter 19), Cinque (1990a, 1992) points out that their relative position with respect to the noun differs in Romance and Germanic languages in a way that is reminiscent of what can be observed with verbs and adverbs. The proposed analysis is thus similar to that for adverbs: The noun moves over the thematic adjective in Italian (or French), but not in English. This is illustrated in (12), where the thematic adjective occupies the basic position of the external argument (SpecNP) in both languages:

(12)
a. *L’[NP
italiana invasione dell’Albania]
the Italian invasion of Albania
b. L’invasione [NP italiana ___ ] dell’Albania
c. L’invasion italienne de l’Albanie
the invasion Italian of Albania
d. *The invasion [NP Italian ___of Albania]

Crucially, (13) below shows that APs (with normal intonation; see the discussion concerning (35) below) cannot be rightward-moved, as they cannot appear on the right of the noun and its complement, meaning that the string in (13) cannot be the result of adjunction of the adjective to the right of the head noun (from prenominal position):
(13) *L’invasione dell’Albania italiana

Motivation for N-movement, just like V-movement, is morphological: it takes place in Romance (to a functional Num(ber) category – more details below) in order for the noun to attach to its number features. It is worth noting that, aside from accounting for the contrasts in (12), the proposal that the noun may undergo head-movement has been the source of substantial research in recent years, and has been shown to have a wide range of consequences concerning the syntax of DP. For instance, with respect to Romance and Germanic languages, Valois (1991a, 1991b, 1996) outlined certain differences between the two language types that can be ascribed to a parameterization of N-movement. Among these are (i) the relative distribution of DP-internal arguments; and (ii) the relative distribution of adjectives in event nominals. Concerning the former, French and English differ with respect to the relative position of the noun and its external argument. In English, the external argument precedes the noun (14a), whereas it follows it in French (14b).

(14)
a. Rembrandt's (agent) portrait of Aristotle (theme)
b. Le portrait de Rembrandt (agent) d’Aristote (theme)

Both English and French having basic S-N-O (and S-V-O) word order, N-movement past the external argument in French derives (14b) while the absence of movement in English derives (14a). In Valois (1991a, 1991b, 1996), movement is to an intermediate Num(ber) Phrase (see Ritter 1991 for arguments in favor of NumP). The (partial) structure of DP is thus as in (15): 4

The second difference between the two language types has to do more directly with the topic at hand, i.e., adjectives, more precisely adjectives in event nominals. This is the topic of the next section.

subsection.heading: 5 DP and clausal structures: adjectives in event nominals
subsection.p: The study of the distribution of adjectives in French and English event nominals Valois 1991a, 1991b, 1996) was conducted in the spirit of drawing parallels between the syntax of clauses and the syntax of DP. Indeed, event (deverbal) nominals form a class of nouns that is very closely connected to verbs. One obvious parallel between clauses and event nominals is the semantic connection between some of their modifiers, e.g., adverbs and adjectives.

For his purpose Valois adopted Travis's (1988) and Rochette's (1990b) position that the first four classes of adverbs discussed by Jackendoff (1972) are reducible to three classes indicating the level of adjunction of the adverb within IP. This is shown in the classification below (labeling is Valois’):

row.entry: Adverbs of the probably class: Jackendoff's Class III
Adverbs of the frequently class: Jackendoff's Classes I and II
Adverbs of the completely class: Jackendoff's Classes I and II

subsection.p: The underlying assumption here is that the positional distribution of adverbs in English is predictable on the basis of their meaning. For instance, manner adverbs (those belonging to the completely class), which modify the VP, are adjoined lower than sentential adverbs (those belonging to the frequently class and those belonging to the probably class). Setting other independent factors (such as transportability) aside, and provided that only one adverb may adjoin to a given projection (Jackendoff 1972), co-occurrences of adverbs generally follow the structural hierarchy imposed by their meaning; that is, adverbs of the probably class, which modify propositions (mapped onto CP according to Rochette 1990b), precede those of the frequently class, which modify events (mapped onto IP or VP), which in turn precede those of the completely class, which modify actions (mapped onto VP). This can be seen in the pairings in (16–18):

(16)
a. They [IP probably [VP completely invaded China]].
b. *They completely probably invaded China.

(17)
a. They [IP frequently [VP completely invaded China]].
b. *They completely frequently invaded China.

(18)
a. They [IP probably [VP frequently invaded China]].
b. *They frequently probably invaded China.
Turning now to adjectives, the assumption is that the classification assumed for adverbs also applies to the corresponding adjectives, as given in the classification below:

entry.i: Classification of adjectives in event nominals (by level of adjunction)

row.entry: frequent class: clever, clumsy, careful, careless, frequent, etc.
complete class: complete, easy, total, bad, mortal, brutal, etc.

subsection.p: According to the stand concerning the parallel syntax of DP and CP, the expectation is for the distribution of the adjectives in the above list to parallel that of the corresponding adverbs; that is, pairings of adjectives belonging to different classes should yield word orders in which adjectives belonging to, say, the complete class follow adjectives of the frequent class, or in which adjectives of the frequent class follow members of the probable class. Looking at English first, we see that this prediction is borne out:

(19)
a. The probable complete invasion of China
b. *The complete probable invasion of China

(20)
a. The frequent complete invasion of China
b. *The complete frequent invasion of China

(21)
a. The probable frequent invasion of China
b. *The frequent probable invasion of China
This follows if, like adverbs, adjectives are adjoined hierarchically according to the class to which they belong, as shown in (22) (see Crisma 1989 on Italian).
(22) [DP probable class [frequent class [complete class [NP invasion of China]]]]
In French, when preceding the head noun, the same distributional constraints operating for adverb ordering can be observed for adjectives, as shown in (23–25).

(23)
a. La probable complète invasion de la Chine
the probable complete invasion of China
b. *La complète probable invasion de la Chine
the complete probable invasion of China

(24)
a. La fréquente complète invasion de la Chine
the frequent complete invasion of China
b. *La complète fréquente invasion de la Chine
the complete frequent invasion of China

(25)
a. Les probables fréquentes invasions de la Chine
the probable frequent invasions of China
b. *Les fréquentes probables invasions de la Chine
the frequent probable invasions of China
However, as in Italian, French adjectives may also appear in postnominal position (thematic adjectives being one case, cf. (12c)), as can be seen in the event nominal constructions in (26): 5

(26)
a. L’invasion probable de la Chine
the invasion probable of China
b. L’invasion fréquènte de la Chine
the invasion frequent of China
c. L’invasion complète de la Chine
the invasion complete of China

This is the unmarked case if, as concluded with respect to (12c), the noun moves past the adjective in French. This in turn begs the question as to the formal mechanisms responsible for the presence of adjectives in prenominal position.

Valois’ answer (which differs from Cinque's 1994 approach, as we discuss in section 6) is that prenominal adjectives are derived via the application of an additional rule that adjoins the adjective to the left (by head-movement), as (27) illustrates: 6

(27)
a. L’invasion probable de la Chine
b. La [probablei [invasion]] ti de la Chine
In (23–25), the presence of two prenominal adjectives indicate that two instances of left-adjunction have taken place. 7

This process is reminiscent of cases of syntactic incorporation (Baker 1988a). One indication that this view might be on the right track is that liaison is (slightly) more acceptable when the adjective is in prenominal position than when it is in postnominal position, presumably because incorporation involves the formation of a ‘tighter’ morphophonological complex (see also Bernstein 1993, who claims that liaison is obligatory with prenominal adjectives but optional in postnominal position, an observation disputed by Bouchard 1998):

(28)
a. Les improbables [z] invasions de la Chine
the improbable
invasions of China
b. Les invasions (?[z]) improbables de la Chine

The alternate pre- and postnominal position, as well as co-occurrence restrictions of adjectives, is given a substantially different analysis by Cinque (1994). The next section presents Cinque's approach on this and other aspects of the syntax of adjectives.

subsection.heading: 6.1 Attributive APs
subsection.p: Cinque (1994) proposes an analysis that differs from Valois’ proposal in two important ways. He proposes that (i) Adjective Phrases (APs) are generated in specifier positions of functional categories; (ii) nouns can undergo partial N-movement, a mechanism responsible for the possibility for an attributive adjective to appear in pre- or postverbal position.

Before moving on to the analysis proper, it should be noted that Cinque revises his initial stand that thematic adjectives are generated in SpecNP. This is motivated by the observed prohibition on the co-occurrence of both manner and thematic adjectives in prenominal position, as in (29a), combined with the fact that the noun moves past a manner adjective, as in (29b):

(29)
a. *?L’aggressione brutale (manner) italiana (thematic) ___ all’Albania
the agression brutal Italian against Albania
b. L’aggressione brutale (manner) all’Albania

If thematic adjectives were generated in SpecNP and the noun could move past a manner adjective, as (29b) shows, (29a) ought to be possible. Cinque's conclusion concerning the ungrammaticality of (29a) is that both manner and thematic adjectives compete for the same position outside NP.
We saw in the previous section that in French some adjectives may appear either pre- or postnominally. This is the case in Italian as well. Compare (29b) with (30):

(30)
La brutale aggressione all’Albania
The brutal aggression of Albania

Cinque's account of the pair of examples differs markedly from Valois’. Rather that assuming incorporation to account for the prenominal position of the adjective in (30), he proposes to base-generate brutale in two different positions in the DP. The motivation behind this is based on Cinque's observation that, although the difference is subtle, (29b) and (30) yield slightly different interpretations: While the adjective in (29b) has a ‘pure’ manner interpretation, it has a subject-oriented interpretation in (30), a result that can clearly not be attributed to the sole application of N-movement. In other words, brutale in (29b) and (30) are two different homophonous adjectives, one (the subject-oriented adjective) being base-generated higher than the position to which the noun moves.

The relationship between the position and interpretation of brutale can be seen by the fact that, in constructions that force the manner interpretation of the AP, the subject-oriented interpretation is unavailable, as shown in (31):

(31)
a. Le aggressioni brutali (manner) vanno severamente condannate.
the aggressions brutal are strongly condemned
b. *Le brutali (subject-oriented) aggressioni vanno severamente condannate.
Subject-oriented APs followed by manner or thematic APs are impossible between N and its complements, suggesting that N does not move past a subject-oriented AP:
(32) *?L’aggressione stupida (subject-oriented) brutale (manner/thematic) all’Albania
the aggression stupid brutal/Italian of Albania
Since subject-oriented adjectives may be preceded by speaker-oriented APs, as in (33), Cinque arrives at the partial structure in (34) (the ___ symbol indicating possible landing sites for N):
(33) ?La probabile (speaker-oriented) stupida (subject-oriented) aggressione dell’Albania
the probable stupid aggression against Albania
(34) [XP speaker-oriented ___ [YP subject-oriented ___ [ZP manner/thematic [NP N . . . ]]]]

subsection.heading: 6.2 Predicative APs
subsection.p: While the word order N-complement-AP is generally not possible (see (13) above), it becomes possible under certain specific conditions. In (35), the sentence is grammatical if there is a sharp intonational break between the complement and the AP:

(35)
La loro aggressione all’Albania BRUTALE
the their aggression of Albania brutal

According to Cinque, the adjective in (35) is a predicative AP, i.e., an AP that is predicated of a maximal projection (here NP; see also Bernstein 1993b; Sleeman 1996). Such APs generally appear after the noun and its complements.

A good test to support the assumption that predication is at play when adjectives follow a noun complement would be to try to insert to the right periphery of the DP an adjective that is not suitable for predication. This is the case for thematic adjectives, which cannot be predicative, as the ungrammaticality of (36a) shows. Indeed the result is not felicitous when the AP appears after the noun complement (36b):

(36)
a. *L’invasion de Jupiter fut martienne.
the invasion of Jupiter was Martian
b. *L’invasion brutale de Jupiter MARTIENNE
the invasion brutal of Jupiter Martian

That post-complement APs are predicative is further supported by the fact that APs that cannot be used predicatively, as evidenced by (37a), cannot appear after N and its complements (37b), although they can appear pre- or postnominally (37c, d):

(37)
a. *Questo motivo è principale.
this reason is main
b. *Questo è il motivo della sua partenza, PRINCIPALE.
this is the reason of his departure, main
c. Questo è
il principale motivo della sua partenza, PRINCIPALE.
this is the main reason of his departure, main
d. Questo è il motivo principale della sua partenza.

Note in passing that the fact that when two adjectives appear in postnominal position the second one is predicative might explain the restriction in Romance on the number of (intonation-free) postnominal adjectives, which seem to be limited to two (this is not discussed in Cinque's article):

(38)
a. Une émission chargée intéressante
a program contentful interesting
b. Une émission tardive intéressante
a program late interesting
c. Une émission tardive chargée
d. *Une émission tardive chargée intéressante
The ungrammaticality of (38d) would follow if adjectival predication, as is the case for the subject-verbal predicate relation, were a ‘one-time’ process.

subsection.heading: 6.3 Adjunction vs. specifiers and serialization of adjectives
subsection.p: While Valois (1991a, 1991b, 1996) proposes that APs are adjoined to Xmax projections within DP, Cinque argues that they should rather appear in specifiers of some DP-internal functional projection, as illustrated in (39) (omitting other potential functional categories, such as NumP):
According to Cinque, there are both conceptual and empirical reasons to prefer this approach to the adjunction analysis. On the conceptual side:
(i) There is an unmarked serialization of the different classes of APs:
poss > cardinal > ordinal > speaker-oriented > subject-oriented > manner/thematic
poss > cardinal > ordinal > quality > size > shape > color > nationality
Adjunction being generally free, Cinque contends that the strict ordering is better rendered if encoded into the tree structure. 8

(ii) There is a clear limit on the number of uncoordinated attributive APs, a fact that is better rendered by imposing a limit on the number of functional projections available in DP rather than limiting the number of adjunctions (although Cinque does not present an analysis of this).
(iii) The specifier analysis does not need to stipulate that APs are base-generated to the left of N, since this follows from the fact that specifiers are always on the left in Romance and Germanic.

Two empirical arguments for this approach are presented: First, APs with complements cannot appear on the left of N (a fact that was attributed to Heavy-AP Shift by Valois (1991a)), as is generally the case for XPs on a left branch:

(40)
a. Il suoi fedeli (*alla causa) sostenitori.
the their faithful (to the cause) supporters
b. Il suoi sostenitori fedeli alla causa.

Second, as we saw in section 2, there is a cross-linguistic regularity in adjective ordering, whether adjectives precede or follow the noun. Again, this would follow from encoding serialization into the tree structure.

subsection.heading: 7 Challenges for the derivational analysis and semantics-based approach
subsection.p: There are outstanding issues that the derivational approaches must address. Bouchard (1998) points out a few in relation to the distribution and the scope of right-adjoined adjectives, as well as to interpretation differences between pre-nominal and postnominal adjectives in French. The main points are discussed below.

Possibly the most important issue that the derivational approaches raise is the mirror image distribution of adjectives one finds when comparing two languages like French and English. Indeed, when looking at classes of adjectives other than those found in event nominals, English adjectives are on the surface ordered in a way that mirrors the ordering found in French: whereas French postnominal adjectives exhibit the order N-ADJ1-ADJ2, English has ADJ2-ADJ1-N. If N-movement were the only factor responsible for the relative distribution of N and ADJ in these two languages, this is unexpected (French, for instance, should be N-ADJ2-ADJ1). In this connection, Lamarche (1991; see also Bouchard 1998) provides the following contrasts:

(41)
a. A huge orange fruit
b. Un fruit orange énorme

(42)
a. A delicious cold chicken
b Un poulet froid délicieux

Lamarche's objection is that, if adjectives were generated prenominally in the same fashion in both French and English, with N-movement in French accounting for word order differences between the two languages, we should obtain: *Un fruit énorme orange instead of (41b). On the basis of such examples, his conclusion is that free adjunction to the right of N in French is a more appropriate analysis than the derivational account (but recall Cinque's objections to free adjunction). If correct, this constitutes a serious problem for the derivational analysis. However, Cinque objects that (41b) is nonetheless compatible with the derivational analysis if the second AP (énorme) is interpreted predicatively, and as such is adjoined to the right periphery of NP. In fact, in their attributive interpretation, the same two French adjectives are ordered exactly as in English (partial N-movement being responsible for the ADJ2-N-ADJ1 order):
(43) Un énorme fruit orange
Bouchard (1998) objects to Cinque's analysis on the basis of two types of examples. Consider first (44):

(44)
a. Le ministre de la défense français
the Minister of defense French
‘The French Minister of Defense’
b. Le ministre de la défense est français.

In this example Bouchard claims that the postnominal (post-complement) adjective appears to receive an interpretation that seems to differ from the one it receives in the predicative construction (44b) (44b refers to the person's nationality more specifically).

The second type of example concerns the relative scope of adjectives. Bouchard's analysis (see below) predicts that, in French, when two adjectives appear postnominally, the rightmost adjective has scope over the other one. This is the case in (41b, 42b) for instance.
In the derivational approach, this is attained by allowing adjectives to be adjoined to the right periphery of the DP and be interpreted predicatively (Cinque 1994; Bernstein 1993b; Sleeman 1996).
Bouchard's objection to this option is based on the following examples:

(45)
a. La distribution de pétrole américaine
b. *La distribution fut américaine.
While in (45a) the adjective can appear on the right periphery of the DP, (45b) shows that it cannot receive a predicative reading.

Although this issue may require further investigation, there seems to be a way to look at the two sets of examples that is till compatible with the derivational approach. The idea is that in both (44a) and (45a), the noun and its complement can be interpreted as a compound. 9 If this is correct, both examples simply represent cases of N-movement past an attributive adjective.

That the noun and its complement form a compound is probably more evident given the absence of a determiner before the noun pétrole in (45a). In fact, addition of a determiner results in ungrammaticality:
(46) *La distribution du (= de le) pétrole américaine

Returning to the mirror image issue, one last remark is in order. There have been additional claims that the mirror image in (41–42) is only apparent. For instance, in Laenzlinger's (2000) analysis of adjective ordering in French, (41b) could be derived from (43) through XP-movement of the string fruit orange to the left of the adjective énorme (much like Cinque's 1999 account of adverb ordering VP-fronting). 10

Turning to Bouchard's (1998) account in more detail, which will lead us to discuss one last apparent challenge to the derivational analysis, his goal is to propose an analysis of the differences between French and English illustrated in the previous sections without recourse to N-movement. His approach is repres-entational and relies on semantic rather than syntactic factors. The analysis is couched in Chomsky's (1995c) Minimalist Program. Here we briefly outline Bouchard's proposal and look at and discuss some of the empirical arguments behind it.
The main aspects of Bouchard's analysis are the following (it should be noted these premises play a role in other syntactic differences between French and English):

li.p: in French, number is in D and has scope over all ADJ;
in English, number is a morphological morpheme on N and has scope over elements on its left;

Number Scope Condition: the element that codes Number in a nominal expression must have scope over the elements that determine the extensity of the expression (complementless adjectives are such elements).

subsection.p: Since number in D governs everything to the right within DP in French, adjectives may be adjoined higher than N, allowing them to be right adjoined to NP in postnominal position. In English however, adjectives are forced to appear in prenominal position attached to N since Number is on N and governs to the left.

Adjectives in French may also appear in prenominal position, some may even appear in either pre- or postnominal position. According to Bouchard, the relative position of the noun and the adjective is semantically based: prenominal adjectives have a non-intersective reading while postnominal adjectives are intersective. The following example illustrates this:

(47)
a. Une ancienne église
an old church
b. Une église ancienne
a church old

In (47a), the denotation is that of a former church while in (47b) it is that of an old church. In other words, the adjective may only be non-restrictive in (47a), while it may only be restrictive in (47b). Bouchard (1998) accounts for this difference in meaning by positing two different base-generated adjunction sites for adjectives (a consequence of his Internal Merging condition): prenominal adjectives are adjoined to N, while postnominal adjectives are adjoined to NP. As such, prenominal adjectives modify components internal to N, while postnominal adjectives modify all components. In other words, in (47b) a property is assigned to the set of individuals determined by the noun, while in (47a) it is not.

According to Bouchard, the contrast in (47) constitutes another challenge to the derivational analysis given the impossibility for N-movement by itself to account for the difference in meaning between the (a) and (b) examples. In fact, there clearly is no plausible reason why N-movement should have an impact on the meaning of the adjective in (47). Bernstein's (1993b) response to cases such as (47) is to posit two homophonous adjectives that are base-generated in different positions within the DP. In (47a) ancienne is an attributive adjective past which the head-noun has moved, while in (47b) the homophonous adjective is base-generated in a position that is higher than the target of N-movement.

It is worth observing that adjectives in event nominals, the analysis of which constitutes one of the main arguments for N-movement, do not exhibit the same meaning differences based on their surface position. Consider (48):

(48)
a. L’invasion brutale de l’Albanie
b. La brutale invasion de l’Albanie

Although Cinque (1994) observed that the interpretation of the adjective in (48a) is that of a manner adjective while (48b) is that of a subject-oriented adjective, to us the difference in interpretation is minimal and certainly not nearly as sharp or along the lines of (47a, b), i.e., that of a non-restrictive vs. a restrictive interpretation.

Bouchard's analysis is presented in reaction to other objections of a conceptual nature to Cinque's (and the general derivational) analysis. Among others, Bouchard questions the nature of the functional categories whose specifiers contain the AP, as well as the mechanisms regulating partial N-movement, i.e., how far can the noun move, and how does it ‘know’ when to stop so that the correct word order is derived? We refer the reader to Bouchard's article for a more detailed discussion of the relative merits of the derivational and the representational analyses.

subsection.heading: 8 Conclusion
subsection.p: After discussing briefly the two main adjective types, i.e., predicative and attributive adjectives, the former further splitting into the intersective and non-intersective type, we looked at some early accounts of the ordering of adjectives problem. We then examined in detail two areas of research that have been developed recently concerning the syntax of adjectives: the ordering of adjectival strings per se, and the relative order of the adjective and the noun it modifies. Attempts at providing a principled account of adjective ordering have taken two different approaches: a derivational account, and a representational account. The derivational analysis derives the various positions of the noun and the adjective via N-movement (partial in the case of Cinque 1994), while the representational analysis is based on semantic features. There is a longer discussion than that presented here of the relative merits of the two analyses in Bouchard's (1998) paper. For instance, Bouchard's objections concerning the nature of the functional categories in Cinque's analysis, as well as the nature and constraints of partial movement, are valid points that must be addressed in further research. But we think that it is important to point this out: It seems that the debate might involve two independent considerations, i.e., (i) the assumptions behind the analyses of adjective distribution per se, and (ii) the arguments for N-movement. To reframe the problem, we might formulate the following questions: (i) Is the derivational account sufficient to account for all aspects of the syntactic distribution of adjectives? (ii) Are the arguments for N-movement (especially those based on the distribution of adjectives in event nominals, which extends to the distribution on DP-internal arguments) still valid?

subsection.p: Thanks to two anonymous reviewers for useful suggestions.

p.span: 1 According to Kamp (1975), predicativeness is described (informally) by the following syllogism:

subsection.p:
(i)
All Xs are Ys.
Z is a member of X.
Therefore Z is a member of Y.

Regarding adjectives, those for which the conclusion of (i) is true are predicative, others are not (they are attributive). According to this assumption, white in (ii) is predicative, but large is not:

(ii)
All mice are mammals.
Freddy is a white mouse.
Therefore Freddy is a white mammal (true).
All mice are mammals.
Freddy is a large mouse.
Therefore Freddy is a large mammal (false).

p.span: 2 This, of course, refers to stringed adjectives, that is, it exludes adjectives linked together by coordinate (e.g., and) or logical (e.g., but) conjunctions, adjectives enumerated with comma intonation, or adjectives that appear in sequences where one of them carries contrastive stress. It also only refers to ‘morphological adjectives’, as some languages, e.g., French, in some cases use different devices to qualify an object (e.g., a wooden chair, une chaise [PP en bois]).

3 Previous surveys had already established some semantics-based ordering of adjectives. Crystal (1971) reports that the order size-age-color-nationality-material is the norm in English, as exemplified in (i):

subsection.p: (i) Those large new red English wooden chairs.
However, he observes some cases where adjectives are interchangeable, as in (ii):

(ii)
a. the cheap comfortable chairs
b. the comfortable cheap chairs
Seiler (1976) has a slightly different view: He claims that anaphoric adjectives precede all others and are followed by affective-evaluating-color-material adjectives. This is illustrated in (iii):
(iii) The aforementioned marvelous beautiful red wooden statue.
Other studies mentioned by Hetzron include Quirk and Greenbaum (1973), Sussex (1974), and Dixon (1977). However, Hetzron points out that these are either not systematic or limited to English.

p.span: 4 The structure is actually more elaborate than (15). For instance, on top of the theme and agent arguments French DPs also allow the presence of a possessor argument (see Valois 1991a, 1991b, 1996 for details). In addition, Valois (1991a, b) advocates a ‘layered’ structure similar to that proposed by Sportiche (1990) which was shown to have some consequences with respect to the syntax of French sentence negation, wh-pied-piping (Moritz and Valois 1994) (see chapter 50), and extraction out of DP.
5 There seems to be a limitation on the number of postnominal adjectives. We return to this in section 6.2.
6 Bernstein (1993b) argues on the other hand that the pre- and postnominal position of an adjective results from the capacity of some adjectives to adjoin to different DP-internal position.

7 The right order of prenominal adjectives (e.g., la probable complète invasion de Jupiter versus *la complète probable invasion de Jupiter) is achieved in Valois (1996) through a more elaborate structure of DP (as proposed in Sportiche 1990). For instance, invasion here is an event nominal which may select both an internal (here Jupiter) and an external (not realized) argument. Each requires its own maximal projection layer, as in (i):

subsection.p: (i) [DP [NumP [NP* [NP invasion de Jupiter]]]]
The adjectives complète and probable are adjoined to NP and NP* respectively.
(ii) [DP [NumP [NP* probable [NP* [NP complète [NP invasion de Jupiter]]]]]]

On its way to Num, the noun first moves to the head on NP*, N*. Complète adjoins to the left of the noun at this point, forming the complex [complète-invasion]. This newly formed complex then moves to Num, followed by adjunction of probable to its left, yielding the right order of prenominal adjectives: [probable [complète-invasion]].

One residual problem with the analysis is mentioned by Valois but no solution is offered at that point: The N-movement analysis he presents predicts that two or more postnominal adjectives should be possible, whereas they are not:
(iii) *L’invasion probable complète de Jupiter
Cinque's (1994) analysis (presented in section 6) offers a solution to this problem.

p.span: 8 Although one might object that adjunction could be regulated by some (semantic) principles which would generate the right ordering, for example in a Montague-style grammar.
